summary: This is an FBI operations order form detailing plans for the arrest of Jeffrey Epstein upon his return to the United States. It includes subject information, site surveys for Teterboro Airport and Epstein's New York residence, vehicle description, operational plan, personnel assignments, and the FBI deadly force policy. The document indicates Epstein was out of the country and a silent hit notification with Customs and Border Protection (CBP) was active.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the FBI arrest operation. The document lists his aliases, physical description, and criminal record as a registered sex offender from his 2008 Florida plea.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to one count of solicitation of prostitution and one count of solicitation of prostitution with a minor in Florida.

events.title: Planned Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: FBI and NYPD plan to arrest Jeffrey Epstein upon his return to the U.S. via Teterboro Airport. A silent hit notification with CBP is in effect. After arrest, a search warrant for his New York residence will be executed.

locations: Teterboro Airport (111 Industrial Ave, Teterboro, NJ 07068)
9 East 71st Street, New York, New York
New York Presbyterian/Cornell Medical Center (525 East 68th Street at York Avenue, Manhattan)
19th Police Precinct (153 East 67th Street, New York, NY)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was a registered sex offender due to his 2008 Florida guilty plea for solicitation of prostitution with a minor.
At the time of this operations order, Epstein was out of the country and a silent hit notification with Customs and Border Protection (CBP) was active to detain him upon his return to the U.S.
The primary planned arrest location was Teterboro Airport in New Jersey, with a subsequent search warrant to be executed at his nearly 19,000 square foot residence at 9 East 71st Street, New York.
The operation involved coordination between the FBI (including FBI Newark), NYPD detectives, and CBP.
The document includes the FBI's deadly force policy, indicating the operational planning considered potential use of force scenarios.
